content: The Act titled "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" focuses on early detection, diagnosis, and interventions for newborns and infants with hearing loss. The Act "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" defines terms like hearing screening and audiologic evaluation for the purpose of early detection and intervention for newborns and infants with hearing loss. The Act "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" defines terms like hearing screening and audiologic evaluation for early detection and intervention in newborns and infants with hearing loss. Medical evaluation by a physician includes history, examination, and medical decision making to diagnose the cause of hearing loss and related conditions. Medical intervention involves the physician providing diagnosis and guidance on treatment options for hearing loss and associated medical disorders. The Act "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" defines terms like hearing screening and audiologic evaluation for early detection and intervention in newborns and infants with hearing loss. Audiologic rehabilitation involves procedures, techniques, and technologies to improve communication abilities in children with hearing loss. Early intervention includes providing services and information to families of children with hearing loss. The Act aims to clarify the purposes of the intervention. The Act "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" aims to authorize statewide newborn and infant hearing screening programs, evaluation, and intervention. It sets goals for all babies to have a hearing screening before leaving the birthing facility and within the first 3 months of life if not born in hospitals in the United States. The Act "Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening and Intervention Act of 1999" emphasizes the importance of early audiologic and medical evaluations for newborns and infants suspected of hearing loss within the first 3 months of life. It also highlights the need for comprehensive screening programs that include audiologic rehabilitation, medical intervention, and early intervention services for infants with hearing loss. Public policy should be based on research to support the unique language needs of deaf or hard-of-hearing children. Children who are deaf or hard-of-hearing have unique language, learning, and communication needs. The Statewide Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening, Evaluation, and Intervention Programs aim to develop and monitor the efficacy of these programs for early intervention. The Statewide Newborn and Infant Hearing Screening, Evaluation, and Intervention Programs aim to provide early intervention for deaf and hard of hearing children through referral to specialized agencies and organizations. Data collection is done for research, evaluation, and policy development purposes. Technical assistance, data management, and applied research are also part of the program. The Public Health Service Act authorizes the Secretary to award grants for technical assistance to State agencies for newborn and infant hearing screening programs. This includes developing standardized procedures for data management, quality monitoring, and cost-effectiveness studies. The Public Health Service Act authorizes grants for newborn and infant hearing screening programs to study costs, effectiveness, causes, and risk factors for congenital hearing loss, evaluate intervention programs, and promote data sharing. The Public Health Service Act authorizes grants for newborn and infant hearing screening programs to study costs, effectiveness, causes, and risk factors for congenital hearing loss, evaluate intervention programs, and promote data sharing. The Director of the National Institutes of Health continues a program of research and development on new screening techniques and technology for hearing loss. Under the Public Health Service Act, the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Director of the National Institutes of Health collaborate with other agencies, including State and local agencies responsible for early intervention services. They also consult with consumer groups serving individuals who are deaf and hard-of-hearing and their families. The Public Health Service Act mandates collaboration between key organizations and professionals serving individuals who are deaf and hard-of-hearing, including national medical and education specialty organizations, qualified professionals, third-party payers, and commercial industries. This collaboration aims to develop policies for the benefit of deaf and hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, toddlers, children, and their families. The Public Health Service Act mandates collaboration between key organizations and professionals to develop policies for newborn and infant hearing screening, evaluation, and intervention programs at the Federal and state levels. The Health Resources and Services Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will assist States in establishing these programs and developing a data collection system. The Act mandates collaboration to develop policies for newborn and infant hearing programs. Authorization of appropriations for screening, evaluation, and intervention programs is provided under subsection (c) and (d). Nothing in the Act preempts State law. $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $8,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and necessary sums for fiscal year 2002 are authorized for these programs. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are authorized appropriations of $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $7,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and necessary funds for fiscal year 2002 under the Public Health Service Act. The National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders is also authorized appropriations for technical assistance, data management, and research for fiscal years 2000 through 2002.
